history.content:
170 + 126 is a pretty good combo, and the difficulty is not unlike a 'level 2'  version of 61b + 70.

I would say it helps to have taken an upper div before to get a gauge of difficulty, as there tends to be less handholding in upper divs.

That being said, 61b + 70 + ee16b is pretty heavy on its own, so you wouldn't notice much change in workload.

It helps also to be passionate about either algorithms or probability or both. 

A lot of people who take 126 really like probability and are there willingly (unlike 70). 170 is a bit more of a core class, so people take it regardless of their interests. I think there is a trend of 126 also being considered more of a core class though, at least in recent semesters.

Most people will find one of the two classes taking more time than the other; if neither subject is of interest, then you might find the workload a bit more difficult.

The workload is weekly problem sets from both classes, and additional labs in 126.

The problem sets in 170 are slightly easier than those in 70; by the time you take 170 you usually have gained a lot of mathematical maturity (from 70, and other classes).

The problems are often related to designing/analyzing an algorithm. The hardest part is in the design, once you "see it", the rest is pretty straightforward.

The problem sets in 126 I found to be harder than those in 70; the first homework or two are about 70 level and cover 70 level probability material.

The labs in 126 are python notebooks where you apply something from class/hw and are generally pretty straightforward.

Overall, if you found 61b + 70 + ee16b manageable, the workload of 126 + 170 should be comparable (imo).

-------------

I had your same schedule freshman year spring semester, and I took 126 + 170 + an easy r5b the following semester. Although I did well in 61b+16b+70, I did find the amount of work to be much greater and found myself working ~85hrs/week to get the grades I wanted. The next semester was much more manageable for me, as it had a lot less work. If you aren't having much trouble with your current schedule, you would breeze through 126 + 170, so I'd recommend adding easier technical, maybe 188, unless you plan on adding a time-consuming extra-curricular to your plate.

170 + 126 is a pretty good combo, and the difficulty is not unlike a 'level 2'  version of 61b + 70.

I would say it helps to have taken an upper div before to get a gauge of difficulty, as there tends to be less handholding in upper divs.

Im currently taking cs70, cs61b, ee16b and I'm doing well in all three and I'm not having a stressful semester. However, they're all lower divs and I wanted to know how those two upper divs would compare to the workload of these three classes.
history.subject: CS170 + EECS 126 Workload
